info.name: JSON API (non-vector) - public preview
info.description:
To execute these non-vector commands in this public preview release of the **JSON API collection**, be sure to:

1. In DataStax [Astra Portal](https://astra.datastax.com/), create an **Astra DB Vector** database.
    
2. When your Astra DB Vector database is Active, click the **Connect** tab. Generate an Application Token with Database Administrator role. Copy and/or download the token's JSON.
3. Define **local variables** here in Postman with values specific to your Astra DB Vector database: In the JSON API calls, you'll need the appropriate values for ASTRA_DB_ID, ASTRA_DB_REGION, ASTRA_DB_KEYSPACE, ASTRA_DB_APPLICATION_TOKEN.
4. Download and install the [Postman app,](https://www.postman.com/downloads/) if you haven't already.
    

**TIP**: After stepping through all the commands, you can reset the example data and start over by executing the final call, deleteCollection.

**NOTE**: Do not use this JSON API public preview software in production. It is intended for development environments only. See the [DataStax Preview Terms](https://www.datastax.com/legal/previewterms).

Also see the [JSON API with Astra DB Vector Search - public preview](https://www.postman.com/datastax/workspace/stargate-cassandra/collection/25879866-51ff01b2-f155-4a2b-b996-f62e956cb745?tab=overview) collection in this Stargate-Cassandra workspace. Its examples include vector-specific features.

Create collection
Create a simple collection
Find Collections

item.description: Create a simple collection with the createCollection operation.

If you haven't already, create an Astra DB Vector database in [Astra Portal](https://astra.datastax.com). On the **Create Database** dialog, specify the namespace (a/k/a the "keyspace") as **purchase_database**. Once that prerequisite is done, you can use the operation in this section to create a simple collection. Subsequent operations occur within this collection.

item.name: find to return multiple documents: filter by online purchase_type
find field stored as array: filter where items = "Extended warranty - 10 years"
find with multi-column filter: purchases by city and state
find with $and, $or: filter seller is either Jim or Jon, and customer is either from New York or Fair Haven
find with $in: filter where city is NY or Fair Haven Copy
find with $exists: filter if field exists
find with $eq: filter if sub document equals given values to get seller data
find with $size: filter to get purchases with 3 items
find with $all in array: purchases having 2 items car and color, plus Extended warranty 10 years
find with $eq: filter purchases having only the 2 items BMW black car, plus Extended warranty 5 years and insurance 5 years
find to get all purchases showing Page 1 results
find with pagingState: to get all purchases showing Page 2 results

item.description: JSON API operations that find data.

item.name: Find and Update data
findOneAndUpdate - upsert--> Query: Set array of tags, multi data type
findOneAndUpdate - unset--> Query: Unset amount from the document
findOneAndUpdate - inc--> Query: Decrease wait list by 1
findOneAndUpdate  - push --> Query: Add data to tags
findOneAndUpdate  - pop --> Query: Remove last data to tags array
findOneAndUpdate  - each - Add multiple elements to array
findOneAndUpdate  - position - Add element to a particular position
findOneAndUpdate  - min and max - no update
findOneAndUpdate  - min and max - Update value
findOneAndUpdate  - addToSet - Add's data to array if value not part of the array
findOneAndUpdate  - Rename a field

item.name: Delete data
deleteOne  - delete by tags value
deleteMany  - delete by status
deleteCollection  - delete by collection name

item.description: JSON API operations that delete data, including an example that deletes the entire collection so that you can start over with the simple_collection.
